newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romanian domestic credits 16.85 pct up in Jan.
newsitem.headline: Romanian domestic credits 16.85 pct up in Jan.

text.p: Romania's domestic credits rose by 16.85 percent in January to 36.76 trillion lei with non-government loans soaring by 19.8 percent, central bank data (BNR) showed on Tuesday.
Hard currency credits soared to 15.2 trillion lei in January from 9.9 trillion last December, triggering a surge in non-government loans, which stood at 32.2 trillion at end-January.
Local bankers said the upswing in hard currency loans was due to a depreciated leu currency, whose reference rate fell to 5,932 to the dollar in January from 4,035 at end-1996.
Credits to Romanian government were almost unchanged at 4.6 trillion lei in January, taking 12.5 percent of domestic loans.
Short-term loans accounted for 82.9 percent of end-January leu loans, which stood at 16.9 trillion lei, flat on December. State companies held 52.3 percent of January's leu loans.
Inflation was 13.7 percent in January, with the year-on- year rate at 76.3 percent. ($=7,744 lei)
